item.description:
The sun will set and the full moon will rise...again...

 ...as we embark on a quiet journey through Portsmouth's Little Harbor.  We might see and hear all sorts of things we would miss during the day.  There might be nighthawks, and owls, and bats at work in the moonlit sky.  Faintly outlined herons stand as quiet sentinels in the waning light until they burst into the air with a croak, and whoosh overhead with giant wingbeats.  Large fish splash out of the water, surprising unsuspecting paddlers, and minnows dance on the surface like raindrops ahead of your boat.

Early autumn is a great time for moonlight paddling because the sun sets a little earlier and the air is still warm enough.  And I have to tell you that the few of us who did this in September were treated to the most amazing experience.  Some things are just worth doing -and this will be the last of the season.  Don't miss it!

Time: Arrive by 6pm or a few mins earlier in time to watch the sunset if you can.  They are often quite pretty from this spot.  We'll launch by 6:20 and stay out until about 8:30pm.  There will be little or no motorboat traffic so that's not a cause for concern.

Clothing: The air and water will be cooler by mid October but hopefully not too cold.  If you have questions about what to wear, please contact me.  If you don't have a wet or dry suit, then fleece and polyester garments (or undergarments) should be sufficient. You might also want to get a pair of wetsuit booties or waterproof boots if your feet get cold.

RENTAL KAYAK AVAILABLE - ask Larry for details.

Lights: Coast Guard regulations require that after sunset all paddle boats show a white light that can be seen from all sides.  This can be a light that attaches to your boat with a suction cup, or a light fastened to your body - preferably your head.  But, you don't want anything too bright because it will blind other paddlers and impede your ability to see and enjoy the moonlight.*   A couple of glow sticks attached to your bow & stern should be sufficient.  Also bring a brighter flashlight or headlamp so you can see the shore when we return.

Note: Flashing or strobe lights should only be used in emergency situations.

* Moonlight not guaranteed!

Time and location are subject to change due to weather, tides, water temperature, and other factors.

Liability Release
AS A CONDITION OF ATTENDING THIS MEETUP, YOU AGREE TO hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer and his heirs, and all members and participants of the Seacoast Outdoors Meetup group from any and all claims for injury, illness, death, and/or property damage including those caused by negligence, ignorance, inexperience and other reasons. You also agree to assume all mental, physical, financial, and/or other risk associated with this meetup. Kayaking, camping, hiking, bicycling, and other activities pose inherent risks and dangers. Participation in these activities is voluntary and dependent upon your own personal judgment.  Fee is for meetup site expenses and planning.
item.name: Sunset/Moonrise Little Harbor Paddle
